question: Thì một trong những, đúng không?
transcript: Thì cái những đấy thì danh từ có phải là số nhiều. Thì mình hãy nhớ thêm cái ad là sau cái danh từ đấy. If it is possible, it will be possible if it is possible. So, when we talk about the concept or the subject, we will be able to watch short videos.

question: When was the last time you had a few days off?
transcript: Oh, I am already, taking many days off as I graduated my grad school a few weeks ago. And the last time actually, I took a day off while I was working is, was, I think it was about two years ago. And, it was before I quit the job and I had to use all, use up all my vacations.

anti_overrating.reason: 'graduated my grad school' (graduated from). 'vacations' (vacation days / leave).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: So what do you usually do when you have days off?
transcript: Oh, I try to make an appointment with many social groups as much as possible. And I just generally enjoy going to events, conferences, parties, or any events that involve social activities.

anti_overrating.reason: 'make an appointment with many social groups' (make plans with / meet up with). 'Appointment' implies formal/professional.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Uses a full range of structures naturally and appropriately.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: And would you usually spend your days off with your parents or with your friends?
transcript: I would prefer to spend my time with my friends more than my parents because I am already living with my parents and I think spending time with my friends is more valuable as it is less accessible to me.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Uses a full range of structures naturally and appropriately.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.

question: And what would you like to do if you had a day off tomorrow, which you said you are taking some days off?
transcript: Basically asking me what I would do tomorrow is, I have actually a conference tomorrow. I am, I am, I am attending a networking event, for, related to my major that I graduated in a few weeks ago.

anti_overrating.reason: 'graduated in a few weeks ago' (graduated from a few weeks ago).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: So, do you think that children sometimes need to make important decisions?
transcript: Yes, and also no, it, it, I think it depends on the, the how serious the issue is. I think children, definitely need to make, definitely have to develop a skill for, decision making. And, I think it can be very important in the future for them. And then, but it also has a, it follows, also follows some risk, element. that is that if the decision, The decision that they making is about to be risky in a way that it can affect their future and their life in general And then I think they should get some help with their decision making But then in the future they will also have to be responsible for themselves and that in order to get be responsible and have some kind of skill in decision making they should definitely try out in some part of their life

anti_overrating.reason: 'The decision that they making' (they are making). 'about to be risky' (going to be risky / is risky). 'get be responsible' (become responsible).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: And what important decisions do teenagers need to make after graduation?
transcript: Oh, after graduating high school. High school, then they will first, well, in Korea, well, there is not much of a choice because they, they are going to university anyway. but I also think some, there should be some options that there are other, something else than going to university. Or they can start working right away or they can try traveling abroad and see the new things that they have never seen before.

anti_overrating.reason: 'something else than going' (something other than going).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: The majority of sentences are error free.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: And who can children turn to for help when making a decision?
transcript: their parents or their guardians or possibly their, their teachers, maybe high school teachers or, mentors in general, who have better, experience, more, far more experience than they are.

anti_overrating.reason: 'more experience than they are' (than they do / than them).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: And do you think advertisements can influence our decisions when shopping?
transcript: Oh definitely. it affects, advertising involves, some part of, sales and marketing, which is designed to affect the buyer's mentality and the, and which will make them want to do this or not want to do this. And, especially for children, it will affect, bigger than the adults.

anti_overrating.reason: 'affect, bigger than the adults' (affect them more than adults).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: Do you like history as a subject in your school and why?
transcript: I have to say no to this unfortunately. I think it all comes down to the way that history was taught in my, in my high school. And unfortunately the teacher that I, that was assigned to my class, she did not do a very good job at it. And so yeah, I would not say history is my favorite subject.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: The majority of sentences are error free.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: The last time you read a book about history?
transcript: I think it is a long time ago and I believe that it was the history textbook. I mean it is pretty cliche I think but like I told you I am not a particularly huge fan of history. So that was the probably the only and last book that I have read.

anti_overrating.reason: 'I think it is a long time ago' (it was).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses a sufficient range of vocabulary.

question: Minor ethnicities?
transcript: I think that is the name. And if you count that as a history museum, then I have paid a visit to that place multiple times, especially when I was a kid. And you know, as a kid, I was pretty amazed with all the stuff that was going on in there. So it was pretty amazing for me as a child.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: The majority of sentences are error free.

question: And number four, do you like watching documentaries or movies related to history?
transcript: Oh yes, definitely. I think that the reason why history is generally considered boring in my country is because of the way that it is taught in our school. And so putting that in films or any other types of media really, you know, changes the perspective of some sort and it really puts emphasis. And it is a way to make history more engaging for youngsters.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Uses a full range of structures naturally and appropriately.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.

question: The next question is, what historical event do you find most interesting?
transcript: I think for me that has to be the Vietnam's Independence Day. it takes place on the 2nd of September, 1945, I remember that. And, and annually, my country has a very big celebration going on for that specific occasion, and so you know how, how much of a deal it is that day.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: The first question is, do you think celebrities should necessarily be good at their field?
transcript: I think it is a foregone conclusion that celebrities have to, have to excel in their field. I am not sure exactly sure how to put this into words, but I feel like celebrities have to have something behind their names other than just their fame in order to become famous and to be popular among other people. personally, I think that there are a couple of people that do not deserve the title of celebrities. I will not mention their names here. But I think that talent is what is something that can keep a celebrity going for a long time. for example, Taylor Swift. I mean, she has been around in the industry for, for 20 years now, actually. And she has been going on very strong. And I think it is solely thanks to her, thanks to her music and thanks to her, all of the talents and all the repertoire that she has. And on the other hand, if you look at some other celebrities, you will notice that some of them have fallen out actually. And you know, and you do not see their names in presses or in headlines anymore. And that I think that definitely a must If the celebrity wants to become if they want to have a sustainable career in this industry then definitely talent is a must So what do you think are the differences between famous people today and those in the past The first thing that comes to me the most striking difference is their presence on social media Back in the days, well, social media was not there at the time. And celebrities at the time mainly used their talent to advertise themselves. And traditional media, for example TV or tea commercials, you know, they only, had to say this, they were not, on the media quite as often. And so it was really hard for the audience to, to get to know them as a person and as an artist.

anti_overrating.reason: 'what is something that' (what / something that). 'fallen out' (fallen off? faded away?). 'names in presses' (in the press). 'tea commercials' (TV commercials?).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: The majority of sentences are error free.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses less common and idiomatic vocabulary skilfully.

question: However, nowadays, as you can see, there are multiple social media platforms that celebrities can advertise themselves on.
transcript: Facebook, TikTok, Instagram, you name it. And even, they can, celebrities can get an additional source of income from these platforms. So really, nowadays you, you literally see them everywhere you go. And yeah, I think that is the most significant difference between celebrities nowadays and in the past.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Uses a full range of structures naturally and appropriately.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.

question: And do you think the media is putting too much attention on famous people?
transcript: I think that it depends on which famous people we are talking about. I mean, if the person is famous and influential, like Taylor Swift, then yes, I think it is definitely the case. I think that the media is really scrutinizing her and, funnily enough, she has mentioned this multiple times in her songs and I think this is the same situation for other influential celebrities. However, if the person is famous but they are not influential at all, then there is no really any reason for the media to pay attention to them and I am speaking this from the perspective of the, of those agencies. yeah, so I think that it ultimately comes down to the level of influence that these celebrities have on the, on the society.

anti_overrating.reason: 'there is no really any reason' (there isn't really any reason / there is really no reason).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: The majority of sentences are error free.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.
